asset.credit: Image courtesy of The Joint Archives of Holland
asset.caption: Pillar Church 1

date.headline: The Afscheiding
date.text: A number of ministers and their congregations secede from the Hervormde Kerk, the state-sanctioned church in the Netherlands. Albertus Van Raalte is among them. The Afscheiding (or “separation”) has begun and many Dutch Christians will leave the Hervormde Kerk in the following years as it becomes more liberal. This conflict also sowed seeds of disagreement that were brought to America.¹ For more on this conflict click here.

asset.credit: Image courtesy of Kris Decker
asset.caption: Windmills in the Netherlands2

date.headline: Potato Blight
date.text: The potato blight that had struck in Ireland arrives in the Netherlands. The resulting economic depression may have been a factor causing some to emmigrate to America.² For more on Dutch emmigrants click here.

asset.credit: Image courtesy of Niels
asset.caption: The Potato Eaters by Van Gogh3

date.headline: Rev. Thomas DeWitt Visits the Netherlands
date.text: Rev. Thomas DeWitt, pastor of an RCA congregation in New York, visits the Netherlands and meets the members of the Christian Seceded Church, the product of the Afscheiding. He begins a column in The Christian Intelligencer, the weekly periodical of the RCA, to inform RCA members of this small group and encourage their support.³ For more on the early RCA click here

asset.credit: Image courtesy of The Joint Archives of Holland
asset.caption: Rev. Thomas DeWitt4

date.headline: Societies to Help Immigrants
date.text: The “Protestant Evangelical Holland Emigrant Society” is founded in Albany, New York by Rev. Isaac N. Wykoff to help any Dutch migrants passing through Albany. Another similar society was started by Rev. DeWitt the next year specifically to help Van Raalte’s group as they immigrated west.4

asset.credit: Image courtesy of Albany Institute of History and Art
asset.caption: Albany, New York5

date.headline: Arrival in West Michigan
date.text: Van Raalte and about fifty immigrants arrive at the shore of Lake Macatawa (formerly known as the Black Lake).5 Click the audio clip on the right to hear Pastor Jon Brown, current pastor of Pillar Church, tell about their arrival.

asset.credit: Click here for the full transcript
asset.caption: Exerpt from interview with Pastor Jon Brown

date.headline: First Peak of Dutch Immigration
date.text: For a variety of reasons, the 1840s saw an increase in Dutch migration to the United States. A myriad of political, religious, agricultural, and economic factors combined and resulted in an exodus of Dutch out of the Netherlands. Van Raalte and many of those who would later join and then leave the RCA numbered among these migrants.6 For more on factors influencing emmigration at this time click here

asset.credit: Image courtesy of The Joint Archives of Holland
asset.caption: Map of the Netherlands6

date.headline: Establishment of Holland Classis
date.text: Soon after arriving in West Michigan, the settlers establish churches and organize them into a larger assembly known as Holland Classis. At its first meeting, Van Raalte brings up the need for Christian schools. However, the settlers barely had enough money for their own homes, let alone a private school. Instead, they established a school using public funds.7 Click the audio clip on the right to hear Dr. Elton Bruins talk about early churches in the colony.

asset.caption: Exerpt from interview with Dr. Elton Bruins

date.headline: Visit from Rev. Isaac N. Wykoff
date.text: Sent by the RCA Board of Domestic Missions to investigate the condition of the Holland colony, Rev. Wykoff reports that there were about seven faithful congregations in the Holland colony. They are eager for assistance since their mother church in the Netherlands was providing little support. Wykoff proposes to the Holland Classis that they join the RCA. According to him, the colonist's only concern is that they are not put under 'ecclesiastical bondage.'8

asset.credit: Image courtesy of The Joint Archives of Holland
asset.caption: Rev. Issac N. Wykoff7

date.headline: Letter Sent to the RCA
date.text: In response to Rev. Wykoff, a group of colonists affirm their agreement with the traditional reformed confessions and express their desire to join the RCA saying, “We therefore seek the highest possible union with God’s church...if so be that she professes and knows the way of salvation”.9 They even write that the flourishing churches in the East have a responsibility to support them.10 This letter was signed in June by twenty-four elders and ministers from the Holland area. However, no church leaders from Graafschap, South Holland, Drenthe, or Grand Rapids congregations sign this document.11

asset.credit: Image courtesy of The Joint Archives of Holland
asset.caption: Van Raalte's Handwriting8

date.headline: Union of 1850
date.text: At their annual meeting, the general synod of the RCA votes to admit the Holland Classis into their denomination. A few months earlier, Rev. Van Raalte had visited Albany “to give and to ask for all necessary information which may facilitate the desired union”, and this meeting finalized the decision.13 Click the audio link on the right to listen to Dr. Elton Bruins talk about the union. For more on the significance of this union for the RCA click here

asset.caption: Exerpt from interview with Dr. Elton Bruins

date.headline: Holland Classis Acknowledges Union
date.text: The minutes from this classis meeting note that the union with the RCA was “a source of joy and gratitude,” showing that the Holland churches officially recognized the union established in the RCA synod. However, no record exists of an official motion in the Holland Classis to join the RCA.14

asset.credit: Image courtesy of The Joint Archives of Holland
asset.caption: Early Log Church9

date.headline: Founding of the Pioneer School
date.text: With the help of funds from the RCA, Van Raalte organizes a secondary school known as the Pioneer School. All teachers were members of the RCA, but instruction was given in the English language despite the continued use of Dutch in the churches. This school would be reorganized into the Holland Academy a few years later.15. Click the audio link to hear Dr. Elton Bruins talk about the significance of the dutch language in the churches and schools.

asset.caption: Exerpt from interview with Dr. Elton Bruins

date.headline: Beginnings of Conflict
date.text: Though the Union of 1850 is complete, not all was peaceful in the Western churches. In 1852, Jacob R. Schepers is called by the South Holland congregation to be their minister. Schepers held disagreements with the RCA and had avoided their examination to be officially ordained. When Holland Classis refuses to recognize him as their minister, the South Holland congregation joins the Associate Reformed Church, another local church denomination.16

asset.credit: Image courtesy of Jack E. Boucher
asset.caption: Interior of Old Brick Church10

date.headline: Rev. Roelof Smit Deposed
date.text: Rev. Roelof Smit is accused of slandering Van Raalte and stirs up controversy over observation of holiday services. He is also absent from a classis vote to found a Christian day school, the English Academy. He believed that this school was a step in the direction of Americanization and therefore away from pure doctrine. When Holland Classis deposes him for his “arbitrary and carnal conduct,” he leaves the denomination with two thirds of the members of the Drenthe congregation.17

asset.credit: Image courtesy of The Joint Archives of Holland
asset.caption: Rev. Roelof Smit11

date.headline: Protests Against Van Raalte
date.text: An elder in the Grand Rapids congregation, Gysbert Hann protests a tract, “Call to the Unconverted” that was promoted by Van Raalte. He said it promoted sentiments that taught that believers had to do good works to be saved. Abraham Krabshuis, an elder in Van Raalte’s congregation, also accuses Van Raalte of not preaching the Heidelberg Catechism.18

asset.credit: Image courtesy of Tim Challies
asset.caption: A copy of the Heidelberg Catechism12

date.headline: Gysbert Haan Withdraws from the RCA
date.text: Seeing no reason to remain linked to a church that was straying from the principles of the 1834 Secession, Haan withdraws from the RCA before he could be disciplined for dissension. Several leaders among the lay people in Grand Rapids, Holland, and Vriesland follow.19

asset.credit: Image courtesy of Calvin College Archives
asset.caption: Gysbert Hann 13

date.headline: Pillar Church Dedicated
date.text: Rev Albertus Van Raalte dedicates the Pillar Church building as the first official church on June 25, 1856. The Pillar Church congregation began when the Dutch migrants first settled in Holland, and their leader, Rev. Van Raalte, was the pastor of Pillar for the first years of its existence.These immigrants worshiped outdoors until a small log chapel was built. The membership of the log church grew too large to continue without a church building, so they began the building of Pillar Church in 1854.20 Click the audio clip to hear Pastor Jon Brown talk about the building of Pillar Church.

date.headline: Mass Secession from the RCA
date.text: Four congregations — Nordeloos, Polkton, Grand Rapids, and Graafschap — send letters of secession to the Holland Classis after voting to “return” to independence from the RCA. The congregations were concerned that the RCA had strayed towards more liberal theology and practices. Their specific complaints were the use of man-made hymns in worship, open communion, and failing to preach the doctrines of total depravity and limited atonement.21 For more information on the reasons behind the secession click here.

asset.credit: Image courtesy of Jessica Cronau
asset.caption: A copy of the Synod of Dort14

date.headline: Formation of the CRC
date.text: Ten delegates from the seceding congregations reaffirm their allegiance to the three forms of unity and officially form the denomination known today as the Christian Reformed Church (CRC).22 (For more info on the names of this denomination click here).They send a letter to their mother church in the Netherlands, the CGKN, expressing a desire to rejoin this church on the grounds of their shared doctrinal convictions saying, “We share with you the same standpoint of being separated from all other protestant denominations.”23 For more on the aftermath of the secession click here. Click the audio clip to hear Pastor Jon Brown talk about the history of the group that formed the CRC.

date.headline: Civil War Starts
date.text: Though both the RCA and CRC supported the Northern cause, they varied in their involvement in the war. For more info click here.

asset.credit: Image courtesy of The Joint Archives of Holland
asset.caption: Dirk Van Raalte in Civil War Uniform15

date.headline: Mergers Rejected by the CRC
date.text: Rev. Vandenbosch of the CRC proposes merging with the Old School Presbyterian Church and Rev. Schepers proposes that they join his denomination, the Associate Reformed Church. Both mergers are rejected by Classis due to differences in liturgy.24

asset.credit: Image Courtesy of Calvin College Archives
asset.caption: Rev. Vanden Bosch16

date.headline: Christian Education Promoted
date.text: Rev. Wilhelmus H. Van Leeuwen, the new pastor of First Grand Rapids CRC is appointed to teach future ministers in his parsonage. He also encourages Classis to found Christian elementary schools.25. For more info on Christian schools in the RCA and CRC click here.

asset.credit: Image courtesy of The Joint Archives of Holland
asset.caption: Forest Grove School, 1880's17

date.headline: Rev. Douwe VanderWerp Becomes Pastor at Graafschap
date.text: Referred to as “The Van Raalte of the CRC” Rev. VanderWerp helped solidify the CRC as a viable denomination. He trained seminary students in his parsonage, was the first editor of the weekly periodical of the CRC, De Wachter, and helped organize five new congregations across the Midwest. He also opened a “Dutch School” to teach children the Dutch language during the summer.26

date.headline: Hope College Officially Chartered
date.text: Hope College is officially recognized as an offical college by the State of Michigan and graduates its first class of eight men. Led by president Phillip Phelps, a minister from the East and friend of Van Raalte, the school’s faculty, board, and students were all closely affiliated with the RCA.27

asset.credit: Image courtesy of The Joint Archives of Holland
asset.caption: Hope College 187518

date.headline: CRC Bans Masonic Lodge Membership
date.text: Masonic lodges in America served as mostly social and business organizations. However, many viewed membership as a sin because of the organizations secrecy, elitism, and roots in the European enlightenment.28 Click the audio clip to hear Dr. Elton Bruins talk about Freemasons in Europe and America.

date.headline: Pillar Church Plants Third Reformed Church
date.text: The church leaders of Pillar Church dedicate a second church called Third Reformed Church to meet the needs of the increased population and demand for church community. Everyone who lived west of Central Ave. went to Third Reformed Church, and everyone who lived east of Central Ave. continued to attend Pillar Church. However, many did not want to leave Pillar Church where Van Raalte was the pastor, so Van Raalte left Michigan to plant churches in Virginia. Third Reformed Church was and still remains an RCA church.29 Click the audio clip to listen to Pastor Jon Brown talk about the planting of Third Reformed Church

date.headline: RCA Adjusts Name
date.text: Formerly known as the Dutch Reformed Church in America, the RCA drops the word 'Dutch' from their name. This may indicate the continued shift towards Americanziation in the denomination.30

asset.caption: Crest of the Reformed Church in America19

date.headline: RCA Confronts Masonic Lodge Membership
date.text: At the annual General Synod meeting, delegates from the Classis of Wisconsin urge the RCA to condemn Masonry, but a large majority votes to take no action on the matter.They unanimously express the opinion that membership in the masonic lodges is a sinful act for a member of the church but make no official statement forbidding membership.31

asset.credit: Image courtesy of Chris Beckett
asset.caption: Freemason Iconography 20

date.headline: Western Churches Urge Action
date.text: At the General Synod of the RCA, Holland Classis and Wisconsin ask the Synod to revisit the matter of Masonic Lodge membership. The Synod forms a committee to further study the issue.32

date.headline: RCA Defers to Local Congregations
date.text: The RCA Synod declares masonry to be an unchristian practice, but refuses to forbid membership in the church law. Though the general sentiment was that church members should not belong to secret societies, many leaders and delegates in the RCA were themselves members of the masonic lodge. They also wanted to respect the right of individual churches to decide on the issue. After this ruling, most of the churches in the Midwest choose to ban church members from joining masonic lodges.33

date.headline: The Controversy Hits Holland
date.text: Two members of First Reformed Church in Holland, MI are discovered to be members of the freemasons. The editor of the Holland City News accurately predicted that the dispute over masonry would soon come to the forefront of discussion and conflict in the churches. He writes, “This is the beginning of an unpleasant controversy.”34

asset.credit: Image courtesy of The Joint Archives of Holland
asset.caption: Eighth Street in Holland, 187621

asset.credit: Image courtesy of The Joint Archives of Holland
asset.caption: Albertus C. Van Raalte 22

date.headline: Hope College Closes Seminary
date.text: The RCA chooses to discontinue theological education at Hope College due to a lack of financial resources. They also appoint G. Henry Mandeville, an Eastern RCA minister and member of the freemasons, to be provisional president of the college during the financial crisis. These actions were widely regarded by the Dutch churches to be a “Masonic plot.”36

date.headline: Anti-Masonic Lecture by Edmond Ronayne
date.text: First Reformed Church hosts a speech by Edmond Ronayne, a former mason and author of a book that compared Masonry to Baal worship and the evils of the Roman Catholic Church. He informs church members there that Freemasonry involves “abominable ceremonies” and requires blind obedience.37

asset.credit: Image courtesy of Scottish Rite Masonic Museum and Library
asset.caption: A poster for one of Edmond Ronayne's many lectures23

date.headline: Special Meeting of Holland Classis
date.text: Led by Rev. Teunis Keppel and Rev. Roelof Pieters, the Holland Classis meets to begin a new movement to fully condemn masonry in the RCA. The churches had found that allowing each local congregation to decide their stance on freemasonry created an unfavorable disunity in the denomination and made discipline ineffective.38

asset.credit: Image courtesy of The Joint Archives of Holland
asset.caption: Rev. Teunis Keppel24 and Rev. Roelof Pieters25

date.headline: Second Peak of Dutch Immigration
date.text: The 1880s were the highpoint of Dutch migration to the U.S. in terms of numbers. Those who embarked for America in the 1880s were almost solely driven by economic opportunity, as compared to the religious dissidents who left in the 1840s. Many immigrants who came to America at this time chose to join the CRC because of their more conservative stance on the issue of freemasonry, helping it grow in numbers.39 For more info on Dutch immigration in the 1880s click here.

asset.credit: Image courtesy of Family Search Wiki
asset.caption: Immigrants Arriving in New York26

date.headline: RCA Synod Confronts Freemasonry (again)
date.text: The General Synod of the RCA receive a full report from the committee that had been studying the issue of masonry and letters of protest from Classis of Holland, Grand River, Illinois, and Wisconsin. After a lengthy debate, the Synod essentially reaffirmed their earlier decisions saying that no member of the RCA should belong to an anti-christian organization but that the churches are “affectionately cautioned against setting up any new or unauthorized tests of communion in the Christian Church.40

date.headline: Holland Classis Dissatisfied
date.text: Delegates to the Holland Classis agree and formally state that “public opinion has almost universally interpreted General Synod’s actions as a decision that Masons were allowed in the communion of the Reformed church.41

date.headline: Saugatuck Congregations Secede
date.text: Saugatuck and East Saugatuck congregations leave the RCA over their tolerance of membership in Masonic Lodges.42

asset.credit: Image Courtesy of Saugatuck-Douglass Historical Society
asset.caption: Map of Saugatuck Township26

date.headline: Holland Classis Resolves to Stay
date.text: The delegates agree once again that no members of masonic lodges should be allowed membership in the church, but resolve to stay in the RCA despite its failings to condemn membership in masonic lodges.43

date.headline: More Congregations Leave the RCA
date.text: The Pillar Church congregation meets and an overwhelming majoriy votes to leave the RCA. Rev. Zwemer and his congregation at Graafschap leave the next day.44

date.headline: Conflict at Pillar Church
date.text: The Holland Classis calls a meeting to deal with the most recent secessions. They plan to meet at Pillar Church, home of the First Reformed Church congregation, but since this congregation had seceded, one of the elders bars the doors with axe handles and refuses to let the classis enter. After rising tensions, the Classis peacefully moved their meeting to a nearby church that had not seceded.45 Click the audio clip to hear Pastor Jon Brown, current pastor of Pillar Church, talk about the secession and conflict.

date.headline: Two Denominations Develop
date.text: During the period of 1880 to 1884, an estimated one tenth of the members of the RCA leave due to its perceived impurity. By 1884, the CRC had established themselves as a pure Dutch reformed church and continued to grow alongside the more Americanized RCA.46 For more information on the significance of the Masonic controversy for the developing CRC click here.

date.headline: Looking Forward
date.text: The RCA and CRC still exist today as two separate denominations. However, their differences are minor when compared to the larger differences both denominations have with other protestant denominations. In 2012 Pillar church officially became a member of both the RCA and CRC denominations, serving as an example of the possibility for future congregations to reconcile. Click the audio clip on the right to hear Pastor Jon Brown talk about how Pillar Church joined both denominations or click here for more on this topic.
